reviewText:
Absolutely wonderful and emotional like any other Shelter Game so far. A huge Rollercoaster of emotions with all good and sad emotions in it. As always a beautiful artstyle and a very atmospheric soundtrack.

However, as much as I love the game and the Shelter Games in generell, this one left me a bit dissappointed. I knew the game was going to be short, but being able to complete it in an hour was a bit too short. I could barely get into the experience, get known to my companion, as the adventure was already over again. I was basically just getting really into it, when it ended. I wished they would have made it just a tiny bit longer.

If you are thinking about getting this game, don't do the same mistake that I did. Explore every Corner of the game and take as much time as you can for every part. I am going to complete the games another couple times, get really into it, collect all the rewards, so complete it carefully, because nonthenless, it's a stunning experient! Don't rush the game!

That said there is not much else I could say about it. The plattformer part in this game works smooth and fits within the entire game, everything is simple and easily understood.

It's overall just Beautiful, short and emotional. It gets you.

Update:
Another + is, that the Devs are incredibly nice people who actually help you with your problems too. Amazing guys! Keep it up!

reviewText:
NOTE my down vote is NOT because this is a bad game! Do read this before making a choice!!!


Where to begin... I guess firstly we take a look at price tag and content. It took me 3 hours for this game because I wanted both endings, the second playthrough finished faster because I knew what I was going for. So is $15 worth for a game of 3 hours? Well I'm here to explain the game and you decide.

Now in Paws unlike the previous titles, you actually play as a cub! A lynx cub. You're separated from family and you're off to an adventure to find them. Along the way you meet a companion and later in the game you will find yourself at a crossroad on which side to pick.

The world did get expanded... a little I guess. There are the same old collectibles as in Shelter 1 and 2 that doesn't really do anything aside from achievements. If anything though, I feel like the world is even more vivid than the previous titles and the atmosphere along with the background music playing during specific parts really set the atmosphere really well.

One part I was at a swamp-like area and the background music really set the mood that this place isn't very welcoming which was fantastic.

The AI is simple and works fine. Although the game still retains the 'feeding' mechanic from the previous titles, it does nothing. You don't get hungry or tired; you can sprint all day and get to the end w/o eating (or at least it seems that way. I didn't try as I ate along the way for immersion). There isn't a hunger/stamina indication so dunno why this is a thing.

The rest of the game's pretty linear as usual but you can explore each section of the game to find collectibles and just indulge yourself in the world. Speaking of indulging yourself, since you're playing as a little cub, you can left click to meow! It's so... ADORABLE. I almost fainted out of cuteness.

Anyways back to the game. The narrative is quite different in this game. Some areas it's okay, there's a clear direction on where to go, other times it can get confusing. I was stuck at one part of the game for roughly 10-15 minutes because I didn't know where to go.

There's also a lack of real danger in the game as dying just resets to last saved point unlike in the previous titles where danger eats your family. Although this could be a feature as it allows you to fully experience the life of a lynx lost in the wilderness trying to return to her family. I know I enjoyed it.

So in conclusion, this game is more lively than its predecessors. Much more beautiful and the endings are both fantastic although I'm in favor for one over the other but that's just me. There are two endings so let that be a thing for you to think about as you play this game; a Friend ending and a Family ending.

**Minor Spoiler**
If you're aiming for the friend ending, when you see foxes, let them attack you.
**Minor Spoiler ended**

So now back to the question for those who has never played this title series before. Is it worth $15 for a 2-3 hour game? It can even be longer if you're the kind of person who likes to achieve everything in a game. However, I was talking about it being a 2-3 hour game so I'll ask another question. How much does it take you to go watch a movie?

Because this is pretty much what it is. It's roughly more or less 1 hour and 40 minutes for the first playthrough as you explore the game and about an hour for the 2nd to reach the 2nd ending. It's dumb they don't have a checkpoint system where you can load back to the split path but whatever.

Treat this as more of a visual novel than anything else. Even 1 manga or a novel is roughly $10.

This is my personal opinion as a GAMER but $15 for a 3 hour game is a NOPE.

On the other side of the coin, as someone who loves cute and cuddly things and a story? $15 is cheap. I have tons of cute things that costed more than just $15.

reviewText:
I have played and loved all the other Shelter games. Each one got me attached to each one of my cute lil cubs and made me overwhelmingly sad if I lost one. This game topped it all. Not only did it make me feel emotional, in the game I was trying to go back. The ending made me sadder than I have been in a game and touched me hte most. Amazing game.

On the down side, it kept crashing a LOT which was annoying. It can be played for around an hour without exploring and the game will end so don't be me and explore as much as you can!

An idea for a new game would be a wolf story. Like a mother wolf and her pups. I have seen a lot of wolf games but I never got the beautiful art style mixed with realistic gameplay. Shelter 1 and Shelter 2 gave that feel and that is why I love Might and Delight. I hope they make more amazing games!

reviewText:
Pros:
- Sweet story
- Nice little levels to explore
- Easy to learn controls
- Family friendly

Cons:
- Short (play time for me was a little over 3 hours). Could've played for hours more.

If you're a fan of the Shelter games, this one is a must have. It has a more concrete story and levels like in Shelter 1, but follows a familiar Lynx cub from Shelter 2. The story is sweet and touching, and exploring the world is just as enjoyable as ever.
Bear in mind that the levels are straightforward and not open world, so the opportunities to explore are limited. On the bright side, there is no chance of getting lost. Puzzles provided are simple, but work well in the game's setting.

There are memories and collectables to collect, so if you're the type to want to 100% games, you might get a few playthroughs out of this, depending on how carefully you search when you play.

If you want a short enjoyable experience, Paws is a wonderful choice. It's just as cute as the trailer would have you believe.

reviewText:
Now this game..this game is truly something. Not a bad 'something', a terrifc 'something'. I don't think I can honestly explain how amazing this game is in a review, man, I could probably talk about it all day. Anywho, I guess I should start my dorkiness of how much I love this game, huh?
When I first heard about this game, around two or so months ago, I was oddly impressed by it, even though not much was known and almost no information was given on it. Through all that, I still found myself loving it to death and wanting to play as soon as possible. Strange, isn't it? Oh well, turns out my interest in it turned out great.
As soon as I could get back on my computer after it released, I was stunned. The title screen alone was beautiful, and the one track of music that had begun playing was just the same. Everything about this game was just..beautiful and amazing.
The game is also only 2 hours long, but with achievments and 2 different endings in mind, it makes a lot of replay-ability!  And taking a look at the scenery and exploring a bunch more is always a fun thing to do in the Shelter series of games.
In short, this game is fantastic. I'm sure that you, whomever is reading this, will love this game if you decide to buy it. Everything about it, from the title screen to the credits, is beautiful, and it's truly an amazing experiance.

reviewText:
NOTE: Please realise this game is not meant to be like the two Shelter games. It is not an animal survival game, but a story driven game about exploration. I see too many people saying it is bad because it is not like the Shelter games. But it is not supposed to be like them.

On to my review then:
Paws.. there is a lot to say. I know you will be seeing me saying to not buy this game, even though I admit: I love it.
This game was great. Storytelling, music, gameplay, the emotions and how Might & Delight have a really good sense for telling stories from an animals perspective.

But then there are the cons. This game is short. Hellishly short. And it saddens me, because I feel like there could have been so much more dangers happening and more bonding between the Lynx cub and her new found friend, the Bear cub.
Despite it being claimed as a puzzle-platformer, there was not very much of either. You do jump a lot and there are some areas that are freakishly well hidden, but it all sums up to not really being in that genre in the long run. If I had to put it anywhere, it's a lot like an explorable storybook, which would be okay if it was longer.

All in All: I am a hardcore (as hardcore as it gets) fan of Shelter 2. But even I can not really recommend this game entirely. It's beautiful, it's stunning and has a lot of exploration to offer, but it falls short on its length and on the platforming, as well as the connection between Lynx and Bear.  Perhaps there will be DLC to iron its issue out, but as it stands right now, you are better off sticking to Shelter 2.

reviewText:
This was the most heartwarming game I`ve played in a long time. These days it is all about guns. But this game tells a magnificent story of friendship. Also family. This by far is one of the best games I have played. I might get the DLC soon, but for now, I`ll stick with the main game. Might and Delight; You are amazing, in every way possible.

Here is a quick summary of the game: (spoilers)








So you start out as a baby lynx, the story starts when your mom just gave birth to you. It is like the shelter 2 opening, but in first person in baby Inna's eyes. After a day or two (I think?) you, your siblings and your mom go outside to hunt. After you are done hunting you go back into the den. At night you and your mom go to a star  Once your are done looking at it, you go back to the den. Next morning, it seems that you are moving out. sadly you get stuck in the lake and you are tooken miles away from your family.

You explore a creepy forest (rainforest?) and you have to smell your mom's foot steps. Then you meet some swans, but not in the best way. they throw you around if you get too close. Once you get passed them you go up the mountain(I don't belive it was a mountain, actually). At the top of this mountain(or ledge) you find a bear, ineed of food. before you saw the bear, wasn't there berries before you saw him? go get them! or if you are feeling evil you can feed him a bird.  Feed him three of the berries.

Once you have him following you, you go on an adventure with him. you'll bump into a misty area. There is a small hole only you can fit into. try to find a way in for the bear. which means leave him behind for now. Once you find a wayy in- wait, there is a fox after you! run! Bam. You got caught. But the bear rushes in and kills the fox. he brings you to a safe place, and gives you a fish to eat.

Now you are awake. Finally. You keep on going on your adventure. Wait- your bear ran away somewhere. Follow him. What is he looking at? Is that another bear? No... to small. It is your mom! But that means you have to leave your friend behind. Once you get back to your mom, keep on meowing, you can still hear him, but now you can't. The en- wait! You wake up in the middle of the night, go to the star, and you can see him. You can even meow, he roars back happily.










Edit: I did leave out a alot of things, and also I found out that you can escape the fox.

Edit 2: Also, sorry if I made a few spelling mistakes, I just type fast, I guess. Also I wanted to move on to something after this review.

reviewText:
NO SPILER REVIEW

Check out my gameplay video here!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kRr6jlkEU4I

Paws is a fantastic game about a kitten getting separated from its mother and needing to find the way back home to its family.

STORY
The story is a very sad one, from the second you see the kitten ripped away from its mother, tofending yourself from various enemies across your travels, even to the last part of the game when you reunite with your family, you must make a choice on what you want to do. It's a very sad and yet a very happy story.

GRAPHICS
Paws has a very interresting artstyle, very similar to N64 graphics. The game is created out of polygons, yet even through that it's a beautiful game. It gets you immersed in the game instantly, the textures on such simple shapes draw you in and make you want to stay. Paws is an admirable game for this reason; I have never found a game that provides this feeling.

GAMEPLAY
This game runs perfectly; at even the highest settings, it runs perfectly for many people. As the graphics are mere polygons, it's not too hard for any PC to handle. The controls are smooth as well, acting like they should properly. The subtlest buttons can do great things however. The LMB has you meow, this is your way on communication. You can talk to other animals this way, and it's too cute for words. One flaw with the gameplay is that when you rotate, you don't go right into facing that direction, the cat has to do an actual turn, which can cause some problems if you're being chased. Though overall, it's perfect.

OVERALL
Overall, this game is amazing. It has a deep story that drags you in from the second it starts to the second it ends. The graphics are simple shapes, yet beautiful and really set the mood for an adventure story. The game runs smoothly as well, reacting as you'd probably want it to. I recommend this game for sure, this game is revolutionary in my opinion, showing something that seems so basic can be an amazing work of art.

RATING
The game gets: 4.5/5

reviewText:
Have you ever wondered what the world looked like through the eyes of a lynx? Perhaps they are your favourite animal or you‚Äôre just interested in the species or animal kingdom. Whatever the case, Paws: A Shelter 2 Game acts as both an educational game and also an immersion into the lynx life. Play as one of four cubs and begin a journey of love, triumph, friendship, loss, survival, and motherhood. Understand the complex relationship between life and nature - the very force that compels the choices we make.

If you are already familiar with the franchise and enjoyed it, in particular Shelter 2, then you will be pleased to know that this game is very similar. It follows the same story line as its predecessor, but differs in that it now allows gamers to experience life through the lens of a young cub. As you control this particular cub you will experience a mother‚Äôs love and patience, a family‚Äôs warmth, and then almost suddenly, desperation and separation. Ultimately, this is a game that will pull at your heartstrings as fast as it will mend them. This is the game that introduces us to Inna.

---------------------------------------------------------
Pros+ This is a game that you can definitely play with your family
+ New characters to meet and explore! The Goose is not a welcomed character though...
+ It's a Might and Delight game, and unfortunately I will always be biased and say they're great
+ Adorable sound effects and music. Very appropriate for the kind of game that this is and helps set the mood
+ You get to play as a lynx cub and piggy back on a bear cub: what more could you want?! Be aware, the bear cub can be quite tempermental
+ As always, Paws: A Shelter 2 Game is set within an artistically pleasing world; the graphics are unique to this franchise and offers real familiarity to those who know and love it

Neutral¬± Like all the other games in this franchise, the achievements take time and dedication to get; they are definitely no walk in the park. Prepare to spend a couple of days toiling over the locations of the rares, etc.
¬± Controls are both easy yet sometimes a hinderance. What I mean is controls are clunky  at times, like when you're trying to catch prey, but easy when you're doing small stuff (like basic maneuvering, running, and jumping)

Cons- To those who have played through the whole game: the ending - what?
- I suggest waiting for this game to go on sale before purchasing it. It's not worth the $14,99 price tag when you'll probably complete it in about 3 hours tops
- You will get lost from time to time. The lack of directions can be annoying and you will be backtracking a lot due to the lack of instructions. In the end, it's not fun at all and does detract from the overall quality of the game
- If you stray far off the path, then be prepared to glitch like hell... I managed to leave the path completely and ended up stuck between 3 tree's. I attempted to jump, crawl, and walk my way out, but to no avail. Out of frustration I ended up just closing the game only to lose all the progress I had made in that session. To say the least, I was furious
- Do you suffer from motion sickness? If yes, then please be aware of your tolerance and take breaks accordingly. I‚Äôm easily affected by motion sickness, sadly, and the camera angles in this makes me feel like I'm aboard a ship. This is the number one flaw of the game, but I can understand the difficulties the developers have in trying to get it just right for every gamer. Mess around a bit with the settings - it may or may not help. As for me, I can only play about 20 minutes of this game before I have to exit it (reason behind my low play time)

---------------------------------------------------------
Experience the raw power of nature and form a valuable bond along your journey. This is a riveting tale of friendship that withstands all odds. It will force you out of your comfort zone at times, and you will think considerably about every tough decision presented before you. While this game does have its issues that it can't seem to iron out, I still highly recommend it if you're a Might and Delight fan. This is a great game to add to your Shelter collection.

All in all, brace yourself for heartbreak and other mood swings, for Paws: A Shelter 2 Game will tug at every ounce of your being.

Overall
6.5/10

reviewText:
Really fun game, only played a little bit of it but so far i have *SPOILERS*




been chased and attacked by a swan and almost peed myself, fallen off a ledge and had to retrace my steps and found that the kit is terrified of water!
Butterflys are a little difficult to catch, but hey, its realistic so who cares, i like how when you crouch you also make yourself smaller and less aware to predators, it would have been nice if you could crouch in the bushes and have you completely invisible as the swan could still see me and hiss at my presence.

All in all, a lovely game and a nice perspective into the world from a kits eyes.

reviewText: I may have cried a lot while playing this game! The graphics are beautiful and the story compelling. It's much more story driven than Shelter 1 and 2, but this isn't to its detriment. You really feal the vulnerability of being a young cub, lost and alone. Your bear companion is a real boost to your mood! I'm sure there was lots to the game I didn't explore, as I concentrated on the story and finding mum. The ending was heart rending, but then comforting. Play this with a box of tissues at your side!

reviewText:
Owch my heart.

Definately got to go back through and play again, certianly missed a fair chunk of things on my first run, even if this installment is more linear akin to Shelter 1, there are still a good big of branching areas and different approaches. Wonderful storytelling through. Both with the game and the book that comes with the Pitter Patter edition.
Sondtrack in and of itself is beautiful as well, and does wonders to further push the envelope of emotion.

While it was a little short, the experience was captivating. For the price tag, I found it fine for containing both the game and the soundtrack. I'd rather have a shorter game thats GOOD than a longer game thats mediocre just to pad the price out with time.

Well done Might&Delight!

reviewText: Shelter 2: paws was not a disappointment with the artwork, as usual, and like it's predecessor, shelter 2, it is open-world.  The music helped show the mood of the game in a very effective way. The controls are easy to learn, the same as Shelter 2. I liked how the hints didn't lead me through the whole game, just handy enough to show me what to do the first time 'round but subtle enough to ignore on other plays. I also appreciated that it isn't just a play-through and you've now seen it all, you need to play it more than once, to build the puzzle pieces. One thing I found difficult though, was camera response, different from shelter 2. No matter how I tinkered with settings the camera never quite followed and gave me the feeling of weights on my cursor. I think this may get better with time though, so don't let it spoil this fantastic game!

reviewText:
While I loved the game, it only lasted around 2 hours. A few parts I was stuck on, and honestly it wasn't worth the amount of money it cost. If you have the money to spare and don't care its basically $15 for 2 hours, then I say go for it. It's cute and entertaining. However, the price is too steep for a one-play and done game. Watching a let's play of the game may be better if you don't want to spend a lot for a couple hours.

Messes with your emtions, though.
****Spoilers****
It really broke my heart to see mama lynx try desperately to save me as I got washed away downstream. It was also heartbreaking to finally find her again but leave my friend behind. He needed his mom too, but he never found her as far as we know. The poor bear was crying as I left and I wasn't able to get back to him, mama lynx kept dragging me home and I never saw him until the end but only as a spirit. I hope he found his mom and is enjoying life. I really hopehe's not dead. </3

reviewText:
The game seemed pretty fun so far and I was really enjoying it. However, the game crashed twice on me as well as freezing quite a few times. While walking and following the normal paths along the mountains, I ended up getting stuck inside the walls and had to close my game and reload a save. I even started floating above the water once I ventured off a log. I stayed there for a bit before the game reloaded me like I fell off a cliff. The game overall is very buggy and still has quite few tweaks to fix.

Would I recommend playing it when it isn't as buggy?
Yes, of course! I love the Shelter series and I really do love the overall art style and stories behind them. I just have a hard time playing when I am crashing and getting stuck in the map's models.

EDIT: Changed review to a 'Yes' versus 'No'. I did overall really enjoy it and I didn't experience any further problems.

reviewText: Another great game from Might & Delight. This game is essentially an improvement on the story telling focused game Shelter 1 done on the new and improved engine from Shelter 2. More of the same fun things you'd expect: A new story, new collectibles and a new feature where the areas of the map are a puzzle piece, each one unlocked by finding a circle of mushrooms in that area, and some new story telling features they haven't used before. Another great soundtrack from Retro Family as well.\n\nJust remember this is a story based game with more puffball mushrooms to pop than animals to eat, so it's not as focused much on hunting this time.

reviewText: First thing you need to know is that this game is short, roughly an hours worth of gameplay if you aren't activitely looking for all the secrets and maybe three hours if you are. I can't see why it was released as a standalone game rather than a DLc or expansion pack for shelter 2, but regardless the game still manages to pack a lot into it's short timeframe. you've got great characters, a harrowing story, some really emotional scenes and two (that i've discovered) wonderful endings that compliment each other perfectly. if it's your first shelter game, probably best to try the second one first, but if you liked both of the other two then you'll certainly enjoy this.

reviewText:
TL;DR: If you want this game, get it on sale. But be aware that it is short and also has a terrible camera and clunky controls. Also if you often get motion sickness from games, this might cause problems for you.

Longer version:

This game is cute. I really really wanted to really enjoy it, even knowing that it was just going to be a short romp.

Unfortunately trying to play with mouse and keyboard was an absolute nightmare. I spent a while just trying to make the camera not a wildly swinging around pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and eventually just gave up and settled on the static camera so I could actually start playing. And even once I did start playing, I had to keep stopping to close my eyes and deep breathe because I was getting incredibly motion sick.

The controls are.. meh. I don't know. It felt like even with the sensitivity turned down trying to move around would often result in me having to zig zag around, making my motion sickness worse. It's weirdly difficult to get back to moving in a straight line.

I'm sure, with a lot of fiddling around, I could have the controls and camera be actually manageable, but who even knows about the motion sickness. It's a real deal breaker for me, though I'm sure I'll try playing again anyway. It's still something you should keep in mind if you also get motion sickness from games.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Paws is a cute little game.  The art style is beautiful as always, and the story is emotional without needing a single word spoken.  I really love this game, and I'll be going back to grab the secrets in another playthrough.  But I just can't recommend this game.\n\n1. Platformer
date:
as stated in the description of the game, is a bit of a stretch.  Basically, you just jump up stairs.

2. The controls are awful.  I used a keyboard & mouse, and had to fiddle with the settings quite a bit to make it playable.  Even with tweaked settings, the camera is hard to work with, and the mouse movements are not precise.  The log bit was probably the worst, as the log would never turn in the direction I wanted.  Who knows, maybe a controller is the only way to go.

3. Game time.  In my eyes, you should be able to have at LEAST as many hours of fun as the game costs.  This game costs $14.99 and my first main playthrough (the fun bit) didn't even last an hour.  To me, this game is worth $4.99 max.

Meow.

reviewText:
I really hate saying no to this game. It's so beautiful. But it's just not the best game. My complaints (spoiler alerts):

-Extremely glitchy. Sometimes when I jump on the bear's back the game freezes. I can hear my movements and my meow, but the screen is just frozen and I have to unplug the cord to my computer.

-The controls are weird and glitchy. Sometimes the controls won't respond. But hey, it could just be my keyboard.

-The game doesn't tell you what to do. Basically a figure-it-out-yourself game. When I found and fed the bear, I knew I could get on its back. After 15 minutes of trying to get on the bear's back, the game finally tells me you have to hold down spacebar.

-Took me 45 minutes to complete the game. I wouldn't say it's worth as much as Shelter 2. If the story was longer, then it'd be worth it.

-The ending.. Where to begin with this? In the middle of the story your mother couldn't save you from the river in time. Luckily, in the area you ended up at, you find your mother's footprints just lying around. You find and feed your bear friend to help you with bigger jumps. A day later your friend senses your mother. You see her across the river. You swim up to her and then you go home and sleep. The end. What? That's it? You don't get to see yourself grow up and be the mother in Shelter 2?

I would recommend this game to anyone that loves roleplaying. I can roleplay, but it's hard with such a terrible ending. If you don't agree with my opinion, that's perfectly fine.

The only reason why I like this game is because it's beautiful, heartwarming, and you can run away from your mother until she catches you. But other than that, not my favorite game.

reviewText:
Might and Delight have certainly gone above and beyond with creating the worlds seen in their Shelter games. Paws: A Shelter 2 Game is a standalone expansion on Shelter 2. The music is absolutely beautiful as usual, and the patchwork style graphics take art seen in gaming to a new level.

Taking the role of a baby lynx learning the basics of survival in the wilderness, you follow your siblings and mother around, eating butterflies and other such critters.

Paws: A Shelter 2 Game weaves a beautiful yet heart-breaking story of a baby lynx who finds itself swept away from it's family by a freak wave. During your time in the wild, you put your recently learned skills to the test and follow the footsteps of your mother. Along the way you come across a friend who helps you get through the rough and unforgiving forest that has become your temporary home.

Will the baby lynx ever find it's mother again? Take a look at our gameplay and review video, then head on over to Steam and get downloading!

Q&A With Might & Delight:
GameReviewsAU:
What prompted you to take Shelter 2 in the opposite direction by putting the player in the paws of one of the baby lynxes?

Might & Delight:
It seemed a natural progression. A fact echoed by a vocal majority of our fans and supporters, who had made it clear they really wanted the chance to assume control of one of the younglings in a Shelter game. They told us what they wanted, we listened and et voila.

GameReviewsAU:
The Shelter series is very much focused on motherhood. Is there a particular reason for you shining the spotlight on mothers?

Might & Delight:
The theme is largely underrepresented in games. Not just motherhood, but parenthood as a whole and the wave of emotions that comes with the responsibility of taking care of young ones. Also, when trying to come up with the original Shelter concept, members of the team were either parents or making their first inroads into parenthood. That played a big part in the games theme.

GameReviewsAU:
Where did you initially get the inspiration for the patchwork graphics seen in each Shelter game?

Might & Delight:
It‚Äôs easy to assume both Shelter 1 and Shelter 2 have the same visual style, but they are born from two separate sources of inspiration. The first games visual style was heavily inspired by Japanese Kamon, which is a form of emblems used to uniquely identify a family or person - not unlike a coat of arms. Whilst the second Shelter was inspired by Russian embroidery ornament patterns.

GameReviewsAU:
Why did you decide to release Paws as a standalone game rather than as DLC for Shelter 2?

Might & Delight:
We felt since the gameplay and story explored different themes to the Shelter series, it warranted a spin-off. If it proves popular we would be open to developing the Paws concept further.

GameReviewsAU:
A lot of people seem to be interested in co-op being implemented in Paws. Do you have plans to make this a reality?

Might & Delight:
We try to listen to feedback from our fans and if there is genuine interest in another Shelter game or co-op then we would be silly to completely ignore it.

GameReviewsAU:
Seeing as Shelter 2 has you playing as the mother lynx, and Paws has you controlling one of the babies, will you ever make a standalone game based on Shelter 1 where you play as a baby badger?

Might & Delight:
Never say never.

GameReviewsAU:
What can gamers expect to see from Might and Delight in the future?

Might & Delight:
We also released what we call a living book along with Paws called The Lonesome Fog. It‚Äôs an opportunity to explore other ways of conveying narrative we‚Äôre excited about. Apart from that stay tuned for more announcements from us in the coming weeks.

Read the full review[gamereviewsau.com]

reviewText:
i would avoid this game if you do not own a controller. the keyboard and mouse controls take a lot of fiddling with to get it to be somewhat playable, but even then it is a constant wrestle with the camera.

the paws method of guiding could have been a little better, as the paws highlight in the direction you're facing. if you're being turned around by the bad keyboard and mouse controls, things can get confusing, meaning accidental back tracking. it was not always immediately obvious where to go (i got stuck on the mountain as a jump to make was not made clear enough).

the game music is a delight, and the sounds are also good. very immersive and whimsical. it's a great game for anyone wanting more out of the shelter universe.

it's a shame the game lets down people that don't own controllers, or prefer not to use them.

reviewText: Might and Delight have done it again. I can't get over how emotional this game is. To put the player though such a harsh feeling. Having achieved in getting the player equally emotionally attached to two parties. And then to be forced to choose... Well, I'll be playing this again and again, when I've got my pieces back together.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nHonestly, it's a very figure-it-out-yourself game but like the other games before - it gets you attached and then completely destroys you emotionally at the end. 10/10 would recommend, will play again.
